fields.title: JS Overview
fields.description: In this lesson we'll talk about JavaScript, its history, client-side and server-side usage, advantages, limitations, imperative vs. declarative programming, development tools, and its current state.

subtopics.title: What is JavaScript?
subtopics.notes: JavaScript is a dynamic computer programming language. It is lightweight and most commonly used as a part of web pages, whose implementations allow client-side script to interact with the user and make dynamic pages. It is an interpreted programming language with object-oriented capabilities. JavaScript was first known as LiveScript, but Netscape changed its name to JavaScript.

subtopics.title: History of JavaScript
subtopics.notes: JavaScript is developed by Brendan Eich, a computer scientist and programmer at Netscape Communications Corporation. The initial name of the JavaScript was 'Mocha'. It was later renamed to 'LiveScript', and then 'JavaScript'. ECMAScript standardized JavaScript in 1996-1997, with subsequent revisions leading up to ECMAScript 2023.

subtopics.title: Client-Side JavaScript
subtopics.notes: Client-side JavaScript is the most common form used in web development. It runs in the user's web browser and allows interactive behavior like form validation, dynamic content updates, and event handling.

subtopics.title: Server-Side JavaScript
subtopics.notes: JavaScript's server-side usage gained prominence with the advent of Node.js. It allows JavaScript to be used beyond the browser, enabling server-side scripting for web applications.

subtopics.title: Advantages of JavaScript
subtopics.notes: JavaScript offers benefits such as reduced server interaction, immediate user feedback, increased interactivity, and the ability to create richer user interfaces.

subtopics.title: Limitations of JavaScript
subtopics.notes: JavaScript has limitations such as lack of file system access, no built-in networking capabilities, and absence of multi-threading support.

subtopics.title: Imperative vs. Declarative JavaScript
subtopics.notes: JavaScript supports both imperative (step-by-step) and declarative (what should be done) programming paradigms. It provides flexibility in coding styles.

subtopics.title: JavaScript Development Tools
subtopics.notes: Development tools like Visual Studio Code and Chrome DevTools are widely used for JavaScript development. These tools enhance productivity and aid in debugging and optimizing code.

subtopics.title: Where is JavaScript Today?
subtopics.notes: JavaScript has evolved significantly, with ES6 (2015) introducing modern features and ES14 (2023) continuing to enhance the language. It remains a pivotal technology in web development.

fields.title: JS Enabling
fields.description: All modern browsers come with built-in support for JavaScript, and it has enabled JavaScript by default. Frequently, you may need to enable or disable this support manually. This chapter explains how to turn JavaScript support on and off in your browsers: Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Firefox, Safari, and Opera.

subtopics.title: JavaScript in Chrome
subtopics.notes:
Here are the steps to turn on or turn off JavaScript in Chrome −
  • Click the Chrome menu at the top right-hand corner of your browser
    • .
  • Select the Settings option. Click on the Privacy and Security tab from the left sidebar. Click Show advanced settings at the end of the page. Next, click on the Site Settings tab. Now, scroll to the bottom of the page, and find the content section. Click on the JavaScript tab in the content section. Here, you can select a radio button to turn JavaScript on or off. Also, you can add the URLS of the custom website to block and unblock JavaScript on particular websites.

subtopics.title: JavaScript in Microsoft Edge
subtopics.notes:
Here are simple steps to turn on or turn off JavaScript in your Microsoft Edge −

Click Edge menu (three dots) at top right-hand corner of the edge browser.
Follow More Tools → Internet Options from the menu.
Select Security tab from the dialog box.
Click the Custom Level button.
Scroll down till you find Scripting option.
Select Enable radio button under Active scripting.
Finally click OK and come out.
To disable JavaScript support in your Microsoft Edge, you need to select Disable radio button under Active scripting.

subtopics.title: JavaScript in Firefox
subtopics.notes:
Here are the steps to turn on or turn off JavaScript in Firefox −

Open a new tab → type about: config in the address bar.
Then you will find the warning dialog. Select I’ll be careful, I promise!
Then you will find the list of configure options in the browser.
In the search bar, type javascript.enabled.
There you will find the option to enable or disable javascript by right-clicking on the value of that option → select toggle.
If javascript.enabled is true, it converts to false upon clicking toggle. If javascript is disabled, it gets enabled upon clicking toggle.

subtopics.title: JavaScript in Safari
subtopics.notes:
When you install the Safari web browser, JavaScript comes installed by default. If you have disabled it and want to enable it, follow the steps below.

Click on the safari menu from the top-left corner.
Select the preferences in the dropdown menu. It will open a new window.
Open the security tab.
Check the Enable JavaScript checkbox in the ‘web content’ section to enable the javascript. You can disable the JavaScript by unchecking the checkbox.
Now, close the preference window and reload the web page.

subtopics.title: JavaScript in Opera
subtopics.notes:
Here are the steps to turn on or turn off JavaScript in Opera −

Follow Tools → Preferences from the menu.
Select the Advanced option from the dialog box.
Select Content from the listed items.
Select Enable JavaScript checkbox.
Finally, click OK and come out.
To disable JavaScript support in your Opera, you should not select the enable JavaScript checkbox.

subtopics.title: Warning for Non-JavaScript Browsers
subtopics.notes:
If you have to do something important using JavaScript, then you can display a warning message to the user using <noscript> tags.

You can add a noscript block immediately after the script block as follows 

<html>
<head>
<script>
document.write("Hello World!")
</script>

<noscript>
Sorry...JavaScript is needed to go ahead.
</noscript>
</head>
<body>
</body>
</html>
Now, if the user's browser does not support JavaScript or JavaScript is not enabled, then the message from </noscript> will be displayed on the screen.
